RT @RobGMacfarlane: A mile of the River Lugg has been bulldozed to destruction.
Bankside trees grubbed out & burnt.
Riverbed scraped out.
Mâ€¦
@DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @WMerciaPolice @HfdsCouncil Do your best. Hopefully with publicity, something might happen.

@Gad__fly @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm Maybe *you* need to actually know what I'm talking about before making sarcastic comments. When they mow prematurely they eradicate the ecosystem that is still active at the time. They only need to wait a couple of weeks for seed to set and inverterbrates to have mated etc

@Gad__fly @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm It's not a meadow, it's fen drain bank, it's meant to have grass. At the time they always mow, it has field scabious and brassy longhorn moths and butterflies, they remove all of that, they could easily wait a couple of weeks until the flowers fade

@DaveThroupEA @NTGates @EnvAgency @NaturalEngland @ForestryComm @WMerciaPolice @HfdsCouncil Reminds me of what the Thames Water Authority did to the upper Lea in 1979, itll take years to recover, if it ever really does. People may argue differently but to me (and the Water Voles) its never really been the same since
@WorcsTravel @worcscc @Wychavon @EnvAgencyMids Oooooh , thereâ€™s a lot of water there.,

Seven years ago over 800 properties in Boston were flooded by a tidal surge.
Fast forward to today the barrier project is now 65% complete with a barrier that can be used in a tidal surge event !
#PrepareActSurvive #BostonBarrier @EnvAgency https://t.co/iiOWzsVhVM
